DOC.HEAD: World Prays and Offers Support For Embattled Romanians
Eds: SUBS 8 grafs for 5-10 pvs, `Britain said...' to UPDATE with reaction in China, Romanian embassy there supports new gov't. Pick up 11th pvs, `In Washington...'
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The world prayed and offered support Saturday for the embattled Romanian people who ousted Nicolae Ceausescu and were fighting to preserve their newly won freedom. As army units backing the popular uprising fought elite police squads supporting Ceausescu, the widespread euphoria over the downfall of the hard-line Communist dictator turned to anxiety over the continuing bloodshed. In Moscow, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told lawmakers that his country was standing by with unspecified aid for the anti-Ceausescu forces. Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov all but ruled out military intervention, saying, ``We have to support them from the point of view of medical help and maybe some other kinds of help, but to bring in forces, I think that's impermissible.'' In Eastern and Western Europe, appeals were launched for money, food and medical supplies. The French government announced it was sending two planes carrying 30 tons of medical equipment and a medical team to Romania. China, apparently taken by surprise by the loss of one of its strongest allies, has made little comment. A Foreign Ministry statement Saturday said the political struggle in Romania was an internal affair of that country and it hoped the turmoil would not affect good relations with China. Britain said it was sending emergency medical supplies, including equipment for treating gundshot wounds and providing blood transfusions. Sweden's government said it had allocated $3.1 million in medical and food assistance. However, East bloc news reports and the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva reported Saturday that emergency supplies were being blockaded. Yugoslav Foreign Secretary Budimir Loncar instructed the Yugoslav Embassy in Bucharest to contact the National Salvation Committee to express his country's support for the ``courageous struggle of the Romanian people for democracy,'' the Tanjug news agency reported. In Czechoslovakia, the Social Democrats opposition group said in a statement that it ``resolutely condemns brutal repressions of the Stalinist regime in Romania, welcomes the fall of bloody dictator Ceausescu and wishes the Romanian people many successes on the path toward a democratic society.'' The Romanian Embassy in China, a longtime supporter of Ceausescu, announced Sunday it fully backs the provisional government that has ousted him from power. Also throwing allegiance behind the new government were the Romanian diplomatic missions in Iran, the Netherlands, Libya, Switzerland, Jordan, Sweden, Turkey, Greece, Poland, Sudan, Spain, Italy, France, East Berlin and Bangladesh. In Washington, Michael Hornblow of the State Department's Task Force on Romania said Romanian Ambassador Ion Stoichici informed the department in writing that he and the embassy staff were aligned with the new government. In Israel, Vice Premier Shimon Peres said, ``Ceausescu was, as you know, on world matters a man for peace; on internal matters a man who used very strong measures like nobody since Stalin.'' From a Jewish point of view, he said, a judgment is not simple because ``he is the only one who recognized Israel from among the Communist countries and continued diplomatic relations.'' The Foreign Office in London announced that it had evacuated nine Britons including the wives and children of some diplomats from Romania. Many East German political, church and citizens groups expressed solidarity with the Romanian people and many called for aid to be sent to Romania. Some set up special bank accounts to collect donations, and one church group appealed to all East Germans with access to foreign currency to give one West German mark for victims of Ceausescu's terror. Poland's pro-Solidarity Gazeta Wyborcza published a four-page special edition Saturday exclusively on the Romanian situation and distributed it free, with a request that 100 zlotys be donated instead to the Polish Red Cross for aid to Romania. The Polish Red Cross broadcast a radio request for humanitarian aid for Romania in the form of money, clothing and medical supplies, especially bandages. It also appealed to blood donors, saying the Polish blood banks would be open late Saturday and on Christmas Eve. The British Red Cross launched a Help Romania appeal and the relief organization Oxfam made an immediate initial grant of $160,000 for medical supplies. Christian Aid said it made a grant of $32,000 through the World Council of Churches to churches in Romania and Hungary. Ion Ratiu, president of the World Union of Free Romanians, said he hoped to return to Bucharest soon and start a mass circulation newspaper. Regarded as a possible future leader, Ratiu told Britain's domestic news agency Press Association from his home in Switzerland that ``if they give me leadership I would be delighted to do it, but I don't want to impose myself on anyone. ``My heart is bleeding for the thousands and thousands of people who have been killed. It is a terribly high price to pay.''
